The circle of his friends included every one worth knowing at Rome,- politicians‚ whether of the aristocratic or democratic factions, literary men, business men, and men ol leisure.

No better proof could be desired of Cicero’s sympathetic nature and manysidedness than the fact that he drew to himself persons of all casces, beliefs, and ages. He wasa friend not only of the eminent jurist Servius Sulpicius Rufus, and the learned antiquary Varro, but also of Caesar’s witty artic-(lc-camp Trebatius, of the clever young politician Caelius, and the accomplished Caerellia.

In his family relations Cicero ,was a true and court· eous husband, a father indulgent to his children, but wisely thoughtful for their interests ln his relations with his wife Terentia he stands in honorable contrast t0 many prominent men of his time, and his divorce from her, which took place after a married life of thirty years, was the almost inevitable result of the lack of sympathy existing between two such opposite natures; and a knowledge of the great frequency of divorce in his day may properly modify the severity of our judgment upon him in this matter.

His second wife Publilia, who was much younger than himself, he probably married for her money,¹ and the union proved utterly disagreeable to him. All the wealth of his affection was bestowed upon his ¹daughter Tullia. Her nature was impressionable like his own, so that she under- stood her father and sympathized with him in his periods

of exaltation and depression, while the unhappiness which ’

followed her through life only served to bring out her father's tenderness.
